unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Let's Be Discrete
question_text: Which of the following situations does not describe a discrete random variable?

choices.text: The number of eggs in a carton of $12\text{ eggs}$ which are found to be cracked or broken.
The number of times a coin will land on heads when tossed $10\text{ times}$.
The number of times in one month that a service technician must be called in to repair the office Xerox machine.
The number of days in one week where Javier will have a substitute teacher in at least one of his classes.
The amount of time it takes an experienced runner to run one mile.

solution:
A random variable is a variable that describes the outcome of some random phenomenon. All of the situations described relate to random phenomena.

A discrete random variable has a countable number of outcomes.

We can count the number of outcomes in Choice 'A' since the only possible outcomes are 0,1,2,3,...11,12.

Likewise, we can count the number of outcomes in Choice 'B' since the only possible outcomes are 0,1,2,3,...9,10.

In Choice 'D', we know that the only possible outcomes are 0,1,2,3,4
or 5
(assuming a 5
-day school week).

We can also count the number of outcomes for Choice 'C' even if we don't know exactly what those outcomes are. It makes sense that we might have to call for repair 0
, 1
or 2
times, all the way up to the number of days in the month.

We may even have to call for repairs several times in one day. The fact remains that the number of times we call for a repair is countable.

Choice 'E' however, represents a continuous situation. Time is continuous. While the tools we use to measure time may only be accurate to a certain decimal, in reality, we cannot truly count all of the different possibilities for the number of minutes, or seconds (or days) it takes to run a mile. Choice 'E' is the correct answer.

Since discrete random variables and continuous random variables are dealt with very differently in statistics, it is important to determine which type of variable you are working with.
